learning_outcomes.description: Explain tissue pathology and wound healing mechanisms, and their relevance to the assessment and management of clients with orthopaedic, rheumatological, vascular, and neurological conditions.

Explain pain mechanisms, and identify and apply pain classifications, to inform appropriate assessment and management of clients with orthopaedic, rheumatological, vascular, and neurological conditions.
Describe a range of orthopaedic, rheumatological, vascular, and neurological conditions in terms of their pathophysiology, clinical presentation, and evidence-based, biopsychosocial management.
Develop and justify safe, effective and client-centred physiotherapy assessments and management plans for clients with a range of orthopaedic, rheumatological, vascular, and neurological conditions.

Safely perform and document physiotherapy assessments and interventions for clients with a range of orthopaedic, rheumatological, vascular, and neurological conditions, demonstrating clinical reasoning and adherence to professional standards.

Apply principles of mobility aid and orthoses prescription to clients with a range of orthopaedic, rheumatological, vascular, and neurological conditions, tailoring interventions to individual needs and current evidence.
Explain and exemplify the role of the physiotherapist within an interdisciplinary healthcare team, with emphasis on collaboration and professional responsibility.
Demonstrate clear, respectful, and responsive communication with clients, carers, and other health professionals to enhance interprofessional collaboration and client-centred care.

Integrate knowledge and clinical reasoning to manage clients with multiple neuromusculoskeletal conditions, applying a holistic, client-centred approach in the context of clinical complexity and uncertainty.

assessments.task_description:
The in-semester written examination will consist of multiple choice questions to test your knowledge (and application of knowledge) on foundations of neuromusculoskeletal physiotherapy. This exam will examine all work covered in weeks 1-5 (inclusive) of semester. It will be an invigilated, on campus, closed book exam.

Feedback: An overall summary of feedback will be provided, including cohort feedback on areas for further development. This will be released after deferred examinations are complete. Requests for further feedback must be submitted in writing to the course coordinator, and must include a reflection on exam performance and specific questions for feedback.

Use of AI technology: This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Please see the Assessment tab on Blackboard for information this assessment item.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Please see the Assessment tab on Blackboard for information about this assessment item.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: Exams submitted after the end of the submission time will incur a late penalty.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
Practical examinations will be scheduled on-campus in a face-to-face format, during the central examination period. The examinable techniques include all practical content and related knowledge from weeks 1-13.

Feedback: Overall summary of feedback will be provided via Blackboard, including cohort feedback on areas for further development. Requests for further feedback must be submitted in writing to the course coordinator, and must include a reflection on exam performance and specific questions for feedback. Additional feedback will be provided within 14 calendar days. End-semester practical exam marks will not be released until after the release of the final grade.

In this course the recording of an assessment (oral/practical) performance has been waived, a record of student performance will be taken by other means such as detailed written notes that can be referred to if a remark is required at a later date.

Use of AI technology: This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
The end of semester written examination will be scheduled on-campus in a face-to-face Inspera format during the central examination period. The end-semester written examination will consist of short answer questions to test your knowledge and the application of that knowledge towards the assessment and management of clients with neuromusculoskeletal conditions. This exam will examine all work covered in the course.

Feedback: Overall summary of feedback will be provided via Blackboard, including cohort feedback on areas for further development. Requests for further feedback must be submitted in writing to the course coordinator, and must include a reflection on exam performance and specific questions for feedback. Additional feedback will be provided within 14 calendar days. End-semester practical exam marks will not be released until after the release of the final grade.

Use of AI technology: This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom O-week To Week 13(16 Feb - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

Lectures will be delivered by expert lecturers from within the School of Health & Rehabilitation Sciences and The University of Queensland, as well as invited guest lecturers from a variety of health professions. Content will be delivered via a combination of pre-recorded online lectures and live in-person lectures as indicated on Blackboard under the course schedule, with up to 4 hours of lecture activity planned each week. Lectures will provide foundational information across a range of topics, including mobility aids; orthoses; tissue pathology and repair processes; pain; and the assessment and management of clients with specific neuromusculoskeletal conditions (e.g. rheumatological disorders, orthopaedic conditions, vascular conditions, amputations, burn injury, spinal cord injury).


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06, L07, L08, L09

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(23 Feb - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Practical Classes (On campus)

A diverse range of learning activities are scheduled for the Friday practical classes. These practical classes will run for 1.5 hours each, and will be delivered by experts from within The University of Queensland as well as invited guest lecturers from a variety of industry settings. Content will cover fundamental physiotherapy assessment and management skills (e.g. mobility aid prescription, neurovascular assessments), as well as assessment and management of individuals with specific neuromusculoskeletal conditions (e.g. orthopaedics, spinal cord injuries, amputations). To prepare effectively, participants must complete the associated preparatory tasks prior to attending (e.g. listen to relevant lectures, watch corresponding skills videos). As the practical classes are an interactive experience, they will not be recorded.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(23 Feb - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Skills videos

Skills videos provide you with demonstrations and explanations of the some of the key skills that you will be practicing in the practical classes. These videos are designed to supplement your learning, and it is expected that you will watch the videos prior to attending the associated practical session. Please refer to Blackboard for more details.

Learning outcomes: L04, L05, L06, L07, L08

learning_activities.topic:
Practical Classes (Off campus)

A once-off off-campus observational practical class at Princess Alexandra Hospital is scheduled in Week 7 (Physiotherapy management of patients with amputations); all students must meet the specified requirements listed on Blackboard and communicated by UQ to attend. Please see Blackboard for more information.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05, L06, L07, L08
